Royal Guard Changing Ceremony – Experience Royal Traditions Witness the captivating spectacle of the traditional Royal Guard Changing Ceremony, complete with vibrant costumes, striking music, and disciplined movements—a fascinating glimpse into Korea’s rich royal heritage. National Folk Museum – Cultural Wonders Explored Dive deeper into Korean culture at the National Folk Museum, exploring collections that bring Korea’s heritage vividly to life, from traditional clothing and crafts to folklore and daily life customs. Shopping Opportunity – Korean Ginseng Center or Amethyst Shop Visit the Korean Ginseng Center or Amethyst shop, renowned spots perfect for exploring prized Korean products. Learn about Korea’s world-famous ginseng, or admire amethysts and discover beautiful souvenirs to bring home. Korean Folk Village – Authentic Cultural Immersion Continue your adventure at the sprawling Korean Folk Village, meticulously recreated from the late Joseon Dynasty era. Featuring over 260 traditional homes representing various regions, stroll through streets brimming with historical ambience, experience authentic crafts, cultural performances, and gain deep insights into Korea’s illustrious past. Return to Seoul & Relaxation Return comfortably to Seoul, reflecting on a day well-spent immersed richly in heritage and traditions. Spend your evening relaxing or exploring culinary delights nearby, as your exciting day gradually winds down.

Seoul - Jeju Island, South Korea: Island Escape: Scenic Flight to Jeju Hotel Pick-Up & Transfer to Gimpo Airport Start your morning leisurely with a delicious breakfast at your hotel. Soon after, your driver will pick you up around 3 hours before your domestic flight departure, ensuring a smooth and relaxed transfer from your hotel to Seoul's Gimpo Airport. Domestic Flight – Seoul to Jeju Island Take a scenic flight to Jeju, Korea’s famous volcanic paradise known widely for its extraordinary natural landscapes. Sit back comfortably and enjoy panoramic views throughout this short and pleasant flight to Korea's southernmost island. Arrival & Transfer in Jeju Island Arrive at Jeju International Airport, the gateway to Korea's premier vacation spot. Upon arrival, you will be warmly greeted by your driver and transferred smoothly to your accommodation, ready to begin your island exploration. Leisure & Relax - Afternoon Free Time Spend the afternoon relaxing, exploring, or simply soaking in Jeju Island's tranquil charm at your own pace. Take advantage of the leisure time by strolling on pristine beaches, savoring fresh local cuisine, or conveniently exploring nearby attractions. Why Jeju? – UNESCO-Listed Natural Wonders Renowned worldwide, Jeju Island’s dramatic volcanic landscapes and mesmerizing lava tubes are proudly recognized by UNESCO as world natural heritage sites. The island effortlessly harmonizes dazzling beaches, majestic waterfalls, dramatic cliffs, mysterious caves, and lush greenery, all complemented by a pleasantly mild climate, making Jeju one of Korea’s beloved travel destinations.

Jeju Island, South Korea: Jeju's Coastal Wonders & Botanical Deli g hts Breakfast & Start of Jeju Island Tour Greet the day with a lovely breakfast at your hotel before embarking on a thrilling full-day exploration of Jeju’s natural treasures. Hyupjae Beach—White Sand Bliss Begin your sightseeing at stunning Hyupjae Beach, beloved for its sparkling turquoise waters, powdery white sands, and breathtaking views of charming islands off the coast. An ideal place for photography and leisurely strolls along the shore. Hallim Park—Botanical Wonderlands Next, step into Hallim Park—famous for its incredible variety of botanical gardens. Wander through the tropical Palm Tree Road, admire striking bonsais at Jeju Stone and Bonsai Garden, relax to the soothing ambience of the Water Garden, and discover rare plants at the Subtropical Botanical Garden. With diverse scenery everywhere you turn, visitors of all ages will be enchanted. O'sulloc Tea Museum—Korea's Tea Culture Head to the renowned O’sulloc Tea Museum, founded by acclaimed Korean cosmetics brand Amore Pacific. Experience the rich tradition and history of Korean tea culture, sample delightful flavors, and wander the sprawling tea fields stretching elegantly around the museum—perfect for memorable photographs and relaxation. Lunch Break—Local Culinary Treats Enjoy a delicious lunch where you’ll sample authentic Jeju dishes and fresh flavors, giving you the energy to continue your afternoon adventure. Sanbang Mountain Cruise—Scenic Coastal Views Relax aboard the Sanbang Mountain Cruise, a fantastic ocean excursion showcasing majestic cliffs, volcanic formations, and breathtaking coastal landscapes. Revel in panoramic ocean views and keep your camera ready to capture stunning seascapes and rugged island contours. Cheonjeyeon Waterfalls—"The" The Pond of God" Your last stop is the strikingly beautiful Cheonjeyeon Falls, fondly called "The Pond of God." Admire its serene, three-tiered cascades and the vividly clear blue ponds surrounded by lush greenery—an idyllic spot to reconnect with nature in tranquility. Return & Relaxation at Your Accommodation After your full day of exploration, comfortably return to your hotel. Reflect on the day's memorable experiences, enjoying a restful and enjoyable evening on beautiful Jeju Island.

Jeju Island - Busan, South Korea: Forests, Folklore & Fascinating Sea - Women Adventure Enjoy Your Hotel Breakfast & Departure Start your day with a hearty breakfast served at your hotel, preparing you for an exciting day of exploration around breathtaking Jeju Island. Jeolmul Natural Forest—Green Haven Beneath a Volcano First, journey into the enchanting Jeolmul Natural Forest, nestled beneath a charming dormant volcanic crater. Stroll through around 300 hectares of leafy cedar trees aged 30-45 years, breathing fresh mountain air and enjoying the tranquility of Jeju’s untouched wilderness. Seongeup Folk Village—Stepping into Cultural Heritage Immerse yourself in local island culture at Seongeup Folk Village. Wander through quaint traditional houses, witness authentic lifestyles, and explore the well-preserved village to get a vivid sense of Jeju Island’s distinctive traditions and historical charm. Haenyeo Museum & Diver Show—Secrets of the Sea Women Continue your cultural discovery at Haenyeo Museum, uniquely dedicated to Jeju’s iconic female divers. Explore lively exhibits, compelling photographs, and historic displays that narrate the courageous lives and oceanic achievements of these UNESCO-recognized Intangible Cultural Heritage bearers. If available, enjoy a spectacular live show featuring authentic Haenyeo divers demonstrating their incredible aquatic skills. Seongsan Ilchulbong Peak—Sunrise Peak Majesty Next, visit the astonishing Seongsan Ilchulbong Peak, a dramatic volcanic formation rising 180 meters above sea level. Created over 5,000 years ago by undersea volcanic activity, this once-separate island grew connected by sands and soils, forming a spectacular peninsula renowned for breathtaking panoramic views and photogenic landscapes. Jeju Stone Park—The Island’s Fascinating Stone Heritage Finally, discover Jeju's unique geological heritage at the remarkable Jeju Stone Park, an ecological museum vividly representing the island's stone-rich culture. Walk scenic paths surrounded by intriguing sculptures and learn about the strong roots that tie the island’s people to its volcanic stone heritage. Transfer & Tour Conclusion at Jeju Airport Your memorable tour concludes around 18:00 pm at Jeju Airport. Reflect on the day's rich experiences and unforgettable sites as you prepare for your next journey onwards, completing an enriching adventure around Korea’s treasured Jeju Island.

Busan - Gyeongju, South Korea: Busan's Coastal Charm & Gyeongju Royal Splendor Hotel Breakfast & Departure Begin your exciting day with a delicious breakfast at your hotel. Meet your friendly guide and get ready for a full-day adventure, experiencing both bustling Busan and historical Gyeongju. Haeundae Beach—Busan’s Sandy Paradise Your tour will kick off at Busan’s most famous beach—Haeundae Beach. Unwind on this 1.5-kilometer pristine stretch of white sand beach, admire glittering waters, and take in splendid coastal views across a tranquil bay. The gently curving coastline and vibrant atmosphere make this the perfect first stop. Dalmaji-gil Road & Haedong Yonggungsa Temple—Coastal Serenity Next, follow scenic Dalmaji-gil Road, renowned for its expansive views of ocean scenes, pristine sandy beaches, lush camellia fields, and evergreen pine forests—declared one of Busan’s eight scenic wonders. Arriving at the stunning Haedong Yonggungsa Temple, located on a dramatic coastline, admire its remarkable architectural harmony with the northern Busan coastlines, and experience the temple’s spiritual atmosphere, serene ocean vistas, and impressive statues. Gamcheon Culture Village—Busan’s Artistic Hillside Wonderland Continue onto Gamcheon Culture Village—known affectionately as "Busan’s Machu Picchu." Delight in colorful houses tightly woven along hillside stairways, artistic murals, quirky art installations, and charming alleyways combining to create an awe-inspiring urban mosaic that begs exploration and countless photos. Jagalchi Fish Market & BIFF Square—Heartbeat of Busan Visit Korea’s largest seafood market—Jagalchi Fish Market—where bustling stalls overflow with fresh seafood, local delicacies, and friendly, energetic vendors. Stroll over to adjacent BIFF Square, lively home of the Busan International Film Festival, and soak in dynamic street-food culture, quirky shops, and vibrant city-life vibes. Traditional Rice Cake Crafting Experience For groups of 8 or more, enjoy a rare opportunity to engage in a traditional Korean rice cake experience, personally guided by a skilled traditional rice cake master. Participate in hands-on rice cake preparation, discovering the authentic flavors and traditions of Korea's treasured cuisine. Taste your delicious, handmade delicacies afterward! Journey to Historical Gyeongju Later, relax during a scenic transfer to the ancient city of Gyeongju, historically rich capital of the Silla Kingdom, renowned as Korea’s “Museum without Walls.” Donggung Palace & Wolji Pond—Majestic Reflections at Night Arriving at twilight, explore Donggung Palace and Wolji Pond, a luxurious retreat historically enjoyed by the Silla Kingdom’s crown prince. As darkness falls, witness the stunning sight of the illuminated Imhaejeon Pavilion gracefully reflected on the tranquil waters of Wolji Pond—a majestic and serene way to conclude your extraordinary tour day.

Gyeongju - Daegu, South Korea: Gyeongju: Timeless Heritage & Daegu City Escape Breakfast & Guide Meeting Start your day leisurely with breakfast at your hotel. At 08:30 am, meet your knowledgeable guide and embark on a fascinating day delving into the glorious historical treasures of Gyeongju, renowned as Korea’s "museum without walls." Gyeongju’s Historical Legacy—A UNESCO Treasure Gyeongju served as the capital of the illustrious Silla Dynasty for almost a thousand years from 57 BC, at the same time when Julius Caesar was conquering Gaul. Today, this ancient city beautifully preserves its invaluable historical heritage throughout, recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage destination. Gyeongju National Museum—Dive Into History Begin your exploration by touring Gyeongju National Museum, housing an exquisite collection of remarkable artifacts and treasures of the Silla Dynasty. Discover captivating exhibits, including magnificent relics, ornate jewelry, ceramics, and Buddhist art pieces that shed light on the rich history and culture of ancient Korea. Cheomseongdae Observatory—Ancient Astronomy Marvel Next, marvel at Cheomseongdae Observatory, the oldest surviving astronomical observatory in Asia, cleverly crafted during the 7th century. Appreciate its unique structure and fascinating history, symbolizing ancient Koreans’ impressive astronomical capabilities and deep connection to the stars. Seokguram Grotto—Sacred Mountain Marvel (UNESCO World Heritage) Afterward, ascend Mount Toham’s serene eastern peak to the gem-like Seokguram Grotto, an exceptional artificial granite cavern temple from the 8th century. Inside the beautifully domed chamber, view an exquisite central Buddha statue along with elegantly sculpted disciples and Bodhisattva figures, portraying profound spirituality and refined artistry of the Silla artisans. Bulguksa Temple—Iconic Beauty & Artistic Stone Relics (UNESCO World Heritage) Experience Bulguksa Temple, renowned globally for its remarkable architectural excellence and artful stone craftsmanship that blend naturally with picturesque surroundings. Visitors from around the world acclaim its beauty and spiritual ambience, making it one of Korea’s most cherished cultural landmarks. Transfer & Overnight Stay in Daegu City After an enriching day exploring Gyeongju’s profound historical legacy, journey comfortably to Daegu, the vibrant heart of Gyeongsang province. Upon arrival, check into your comfortable hotel and enjoy leisurely time unwinding, reflecting on your wonderful day's journey through Korea’s dazzling past.

Daegu - Pyeongchang, South Korea: Sacred Temples, Traditional Villages & Olympic Heritage Hotel Check-out & Start of Day’s Journey Depart comfortably in the morning after breakfast and hotel check-out, ready to delve into Korea’s incredible religious and historical heritage and Olympic legacy. Haeinsa Temple—Sacred Treasures of Gayasan (UNESCO World Heritage) Begin your adventure at stunning Haeinsa Temple, nestled in lush Gayasan National Park. Founded in 802 AD by King Ae-Jang of the Silla Dynasty, Haeinsa Temple is famed for safeguarding Korea’s priceless national treasure—the Tripitaka Koreana. Comprising precisely 81,341 meticulously carved wooden blocks, this extensive collection served as a spiritual defense against the Mongol invasions. Marvel at the exceptional craftsmanship, historical significance, and serene mountain surroundings that create an atmosphere of profound calm and reverence. Andong Hahoe Folk Village—Timeless Joseon Charm (UNESCO World Heritage) Continue onward to Andong Hahoe Village, a beautifully preserved, authentically inhabited traditional village reflecting the architecture and social structures of the Joseon Dynasty period. Unlike a staged tourist site, Hahoe remains lively and inhabited, allowing visitors a rare glimpse into the everyday life and traditions of centuries-old Korean society. The village became internationally renowned following the memorable visit by Queen Elizabeth II a few decades ago, solidifying its status as a global cultural treasure. Immerse yourself in narrow alleyways, admire historic residences, see traditional crafts, and talk with friendly villagers to truly capture the essence of Korea’s past. Travel to Olympic City—Pyeongchang Lastly, comfortably journey onward to Pyeongchang, the remarkable host city for the 2018 Winter Olympics, proudly showcasing its modern history alongside a picturesque natural setting. Enjoy the ever-changing landscapes as you travel to this scenic mountain city, experiencing the charm and excitement that accompanied the Olympic legacy. Upon arrival, settle into your accommodation and take a rest, reflecting on an extraordinary day exploring Korea’s rich spiritual traditions, cultural heritage, and global legacy.

Pyeongchang - Seoul, South Korea: Temple Serenity & Majestic Seoraksan Adventure Breakfast & Departure from Hotel Start your day refreshed with a delicious breakfast, and prepare yourself for an enriching experience amidst Korea’s natural beauty and spiritual heritage. Woljeongsa Temple—Immersive Temple Experience Travel to tranquil Woljeongsa Temple, nestled within pristine forests and serene landscapes. Engage in unique temple-stay activities: learn proper temple etiquette, explore historic temple grounds throughout a guided tour, participate in walking meditation within lush surroundings, or engage in an insightful, enlightening conversation with a resident monk. Enjoy a traditional monastic meal, savoring simplicity and mindfulness in eating—providing unforgettable memories and spiritual awakening. (This experience is available only for groups of 8 or more participants.) Seoraksan National Park—Natural Splendor (UNESCO Biosphere Reserve) Continue onward to Korea’s beloved and celebrated Seoraksan National Park, a majestic natural paradise where jagged mountain peaks pierce through drifting clouds and crystalline jade-colored waters flow peacefully through scenic valleys. Recognized by UNESCO in 1982 for its exceptionally rich biodiversity, Seoraksan promises breathtaking views, dramatic landscapes, and countless opportunities for stunning photography and exploration. Sinheungsa Temple—Ancient Heritage Amid Majestic Scenery Visit historic Sinheungsa Temple, beautifully situated within the mountainous embrace of Mt. Seorak. Built by the respected monk Jajangyulsa in the 7th century (590~658), the temple offers a rich tapestry of Korean history, spectacular architecture, serene spirituality, and a chance to quietly reflect within its tranquil grounds. Return to Seoul & Hotel Drop-off After fulfilling your day amongst the mountains and serene temples, relax comfortably during your journey back to vibrant Seoul. Reflect on the unforgettable experiences of the day and Korea’s remarkable natural and spiritual beauty as you return leisurely to the bustling capital city before checking into your hotel for a well-earned rest.

Seoul, South Korea: DMZ Exploration: Witness History & Hope Morning Departure Enjoy an early breakfast at your hotel before meeting your guide promptly, Don't forget your passport—it’s necessary for admission to the DMZ area. Imjingak Park – Symbol of Peace & Remembrance Your unforgettable journey begins at Imjingak Park. This poignant site symbolizes both unity and remembrance, illustrated with powerful monuments and beautiful memorials dedicated to peace and reunification efforts on the Korean peninsula. The Unification Bridge & Security Checkpoint Cross the historic Unification Bridge, noting its significance as you prepare for your entry into the heavily fortified Demilitarized Zone (DMZ). Proceed smoothly through mandatory security and identification checks by military personnel. DMZ Theater & Exhibition Hall – Insights of Division Discover deeper histories and true stories inside the DMZ Theater and Exhibition Hall, offering compelling visual insights into the Korean conflict and sharing powerful messages of hope for a unified nation. The 3rd Infiltration Tunnel – The Hidden Passage Descend into the intriguing 3rd Infiltration Tunnel, a secret pathway built beneath the border aimed at infiltration. Experience firsthand the atmosphere of tension combined with curiosity, gaining insight into this symbolic site of the divided Korea. Dora Observatory – Peek into the North From Dora Observatory, catch a unique and unforgettable panoramic view directly into North Korea—their towns, propaganda villages, flags, and remnants of a divided nation. This observation platform is the closest visitors can officially come to the North Korean side, making the experience exceptionally memorable. Dorasan Station – Last Train Stop to the North Explore historic Dorasan Station—the northernmost railway stop in South Korea and a symbolic place representing collective hope and reunification dreams, awaiting the day trains can freely journey beyond borders. Shopping Experience – Amethyst or Ginseng Center Your tour will finish with a short visit to either a prominent Amethyst or Ginseng Center. Discover exquisite amethyst jewelry or famed Korean Ginseng products—making perfect souvenirs and gifts embodying Korean culture and history. Tour Conclusion & Drop-off at Seoul City Hall The tour concludes at central Seoul City Hall, conveniently located for you to independently explore lively avenues, charming alleys, or bustling shopping districts. Return leisurely to your hotel by taxi, subway, or enjoy a pleasant walk soaking in the vibrant city life.

Seoul, South Korea: Farewell Seoul: Comfortable Departure & Fond Memories Breakfast & Leisurely Morning at Hotel Begin your last morning in Seoul with a pleasant and relaxing breakfast served at your hotel. Take a moment to reflect on the unforgettable experiences and rich memories you've created throughout your Korean journey. Convenient Hotel Pickup & Airport Transfer (4 Hours Before Flight Departure) After breakfast, our driver will greet you at your hotel lobby 4 hours prior to your flight's scheduled departure. Relax during your comfortable and leisurely transfer back to Incheon International Airport, allowing you ample time for smooth check-in procedures and hassle-free flight preparation. As you head toward the airport, reminisce about your captivating experiences throughout Korea, from bustling city adventures to tranquil nature explorations. We wish you a safe journey home, carrying with you cherished memories and stories to share with family and friends.

generalInfo:
South Korea is the rarest of the rare: a country that’s packed to bursting with quirks, charm and cultural riches, but that still – for now – feels like something of a joyous secret. In this South Korea: Cities & Culture itinerary you will discover the history which has shaped the country’s unique cultural identity, as well as experience first-hand the Korean Wave (Hallyu) of culture which has burst onto the international scene and gained global popularity.

Beginning in the capital, Seoul, you’ll be introduced to some of the country’s most popular street food on an evening tour of the city, where you’ll explore Gwangjang Market and visit a delicious indoor Korean barbeque restaurant.

A full day tour of the city’s historical and cultural sights is also included. Explore the UNESCO World Heritage Changdeokgung Palace, which was built in the early 15th century and credited with influencing Korean architecture and landscaping for generations. Head to Bukchon, a picturesque district of low-rise hanok houses that provides a remarkably well-preserved glimpse of old Korea. Visit Myeongdong shopping street, Korea's best-known shopping and fashion district.

You’ll also venture out to the 18th century Hwaseong Fortress, and Haenggung Palace, in the neighbouring city of Suwon. Here there’ll be opportunities for more cultural interaction at Hanggungdong Mural Village, which is made up of craft stores, workshops and street food stalls, set amongst buildings decorated with pretty murals.

After taking the high-speed KTX bullet train south to the city of Jeonju, you will be free to discover its traditional hanok village, and other cultural sights, independently. Be sure to try bibimbap, one of Korea’s best-known dishes and a local speciality. Spend the night in a traditional hanok house then transfer to Busan, South Korea’s second largest city known for its port and golden sandy beaches.

In Busan, have a go at making some traditional dishes yourself, at a professionally guided communal cooking class which also includes homemade sauce tasting. With a belly full of delicious food, you’ll head out with your guide to discover some of the city’s cultural gems. Stroll around Gamcheon Culture Village, a former shanty town transformed by artists into a living art gallery where numerous shops and cafes have sprung up selling locally made handicrafts. Visit historical markets which have fascinating stories behind their creation and try some local seafood specialities. Head up Busan Tower for spectacular views over the neon city.

dayInfo.description: SEOUL: On arrival at Incheon Airport, you’ll be met by your driver and transferred to your accommodation in the centre of Seoul. Meet your guide in the evening for a tour of the city’s nightlife, street food and Korean barbeque. Begin at a local barbeque restaurant where meat and vegetables are marinated in sesame oil, soy sauce and garlic before being cooked at the centre of your table. It sounds simple, but the food is delicious, and this will be the perfect opportunity to learn about Korean food and drink etiquette. From here, continue on to Gwangjang Market, stopping to try some traditional rice cakes en-route. The market is one of the oldest in South Korea and you can find a variety of different street food here. Try some specialities, such as soondae sausages, tteokbokki rice cakes in chilli sauce and gimbap (rice rolls). Your guide will talk about some of the more unusual ingredients which make up these dishes before leaving you to continue exploring the city’s nightlife independently or head back to the hotel.

SEOUL: Meet your guide this morning and use the city’s excellent public transport network to explore some historical and cultural sights. First, head to Changdeokgung Palace, one of the five great palaces of Seoul and a World Heritage Site. Built by King Taejong in the early 15th century, Changdeokgung was designed as a secondary palace to Gyeongbokgung (the main Joseon palace), and is credited with having influenced Korean architecture and garden design for centuries. It is particularly noted for its sophisticated “Secret Garden” design, which takes into account Confucian pungsu principles (Korean feng shui) and adapts to the local topography. After exploring the palace, head to Bukchon, a picturesque district of low-rise hanok houses that provides a remarkably well-preserved glimpse of old Korea. Today, many of the hanok have been converted into museums and workshops, including a superb folk-art gallery, a collection of traditional Korean embroidery, and a museum displaying artefacts of everyday life donated by the residents of Bukchon. End the day flashing forward through the centuries to experience cutting-edge Seoul with a visit to the glitzy Myeongdong shopping street, Korea's best-known shopping and fashion district. A great place for people-watching, to enjoy tasty local snacks and to experience 21st Century Seoul in all its glory.

SEOUL: Meet your guide and head to Suwon, a city 30 kilometres south of Seoul. The only remaining completely walled city in Korea, Suwon is best-known as the home of Hwaseong Fortress, which was built in the 18th century by King Jeongjo to house the remains of his father after his gruesome execution. Designated a World Heritage Site in 1997, Hwaseong is widely considered a paragon of fortress design, combining the latest developments in military architecture from both Eastern and Western traditions. If you choose to, there’s also the opportunity to take part in a traditional Korean archery session here. Next you’ll move on to Haenggung palace where the royal family retreated during times of war, and where King Jeongju often visited to pay respects to his father who is entombed here. Together with the fortress, this palace represents the power-strengthening policies of the royals and had played a significant role in Korean political and military history. Finally, you’ll head over to explore Hanggungdong Mural Village which extends from the fortress with a mix of craft stores & workshops, artful murals, and street food stalls.

JEONJU: Use public transport to make your own way to Seoul Station and use your pre-booked ticket to board the high-speed KTX bullet train to Jeonju, Korea’s culinary capital. On arrival at Jeonju Station, use public transport to travel to your nearby traditional hanok accommodation. The afternoon will be free to independently explore this official UNESCO City of Gastronomy. Mandu dumplings, baguettes stuffed with spicy pork, bibimbap with mung bean jelly and cinnamon-flavoured moju liquor are just a few of the items on the menu. Be sure to check out “Makgeolli Town”, where entire streets are devoted to the enjoyment of the local tipple, makgeolli, a milk-white rice wine that’s served in a copper kettle. Buy a kettle to share and the food gets thrown in for free (although the locals will tell you makgeolli is a food, not a beverage). Jeonju is not only known for its fantastic cuisine, it’s also home to a beautifully preserved maze of alleys and old-fashioned, slate-roofed hanok houses that have been converted into cafés, restaurants, boutiques, guesthouses and craft workshops. If you feel up for a hike, schlep to the top of Martyr’s Mountain, the final resting place of thirteen Korean Catholics who were persecuted in the 18th century, or head up to Omokdae’s hillside pavilion for panoramic views over the town and surrounding hills.

BUSAN: Meet your driver and take a private transfer to Busan, South Korea’s second largest city, located on the southeast coast. This port town is home to several sandy beaches and is a favourite weekend getaway for many Koreans. The afternoon will be free at leisure, and we recommend a trip to the Buddhist temple Haedong Yonggungsa, which is easily accessible by public bus. Built in 1376 during the Goryeo dynasty, it differs from most other temples in Korea as it is one of the few to be found on Busan’s stunning coastline instead of in the mountains. Devoted to the Goddess Buddha of Mercy, it is one of only three temples dedicated to her and its motto promises at least one of your wishes to be granted through prayer here. Afterwards you can head to the Haeundae beach area to relax or explore the lively restaurant scene.

BUSAN: This morning you’ll join a shared cooking class which includes Korean homemade sauce tasting. Be guided by experienced chefs for an in-depth lesson on how to create your own authentic Korean dishes made from fresh, seasonal ingredients with a side of Korean culture thrown in. Afterwards you’ll try the fruits of your labour. In the afternoon, you’ll be taken on a tour of the city’s cultural highlights. Visit the higgledy-piggledy alleys and pastel-coloured houses of Gamcheon Culture Village. Gamcheon began life as a shanty town in the 1920s and 30s, sprawling across a steep mountainside overlooking the South Sea. In 2009, however, the local government collaborated with artists to transform the district into a living art gallery, and today the area is stuffed to the gills with sculptures, murals, and street art of all kinds - as well as numerous trendy cafés and shops selling locally made handicrafts. The renovation project has been a resounding success, and Gamcheon today is a magnet for art-lovers of all stripes - so expect to queue for that perfect selfie in front of the stunning views! Stop at Kukje International Market, where slow trains trundle through on their way to refuel the nearby US army base, and you can find selling everything from flowers and street snacks to K-Pop merchandise and knock-off Dolce & Gabbana bags. Busan is the 5th busiest port in the world so it should come as no surprise that it’s one of Korea’s best destinations for seafood. Next you will head to Busan’s most famous seafood market; Jagalchi. Here you’ll wander amongst the aquarium-like stalls, and sample some of the local produce like nakji octopus tentacles or perhaps some maeu un tanng (fish soup). Your final stop will be Yongdusan Park and Busan Tower where you will learn about Korea’s naval history from the statue of Admiral Yi Shun-sin and enjoy spectacular views over the city.

SEOUL: Use public transport to make your way to Busan Station and use your pre-booked ticket to board the high-speed KTX bullet train back to Seoul. On arrival at Seoul Station, use public transport to travel to your centrally located hotel. The remainder of the day will be free at leisure to finish off your exploration of the capital. There’s plenty more to see and do. Hongdae and Edae in the west are the creative hotspots, where you’ll find trendy cafés and bars, vintage shops, and a vibrant, alternative nightlife scene. Gangnam, made famous by the 2012 smash-hit song, is where you’ll find luxurious skyscrapers, upmarket shopping malls, and the biggest and best clubs in South Korea. Sip soju at a streetside tent bar, relax at a traditional jimjilbang bathhouse, go gallery-hopping in Samcheong-dong, or sing your heart out at one of the city’s many self-serve karaoke spots.
SEOUL: Meet your driver this morning for a private transfer to Incehon Airport for your onward international flight.

generalInfo:
From bustling, neon-lit metropolises to rolling countryside hills, long sandy beaches to temples in the mountains, and even a visit to the historic Demilitarized Zone on the border with North Korea, our adventure leaders will take you off the beaten track and show you local life on this unforgettable South Korean experience.

Included in all tours:

An epic Adventure Leader, aka a local legend, to turn your trip into the adventure of a lifetime
Local transport within South Korea, excluding airport transfers upon arrival in South Korea and transport for optional activities.
Accommodation (including hostels and 1-night templestay)

Accommodation style:

In true backpacking style, our accommodation is in shared, mixed-gender dorm rooms as standard on this tour. But if you’d prefer a little extra comfort and your own space to relax after an action-packed day, room upgrades are available. Please request this on booking.

Included activities:

Taekwondo Class (Seoul)
Group Dinner at Myeongdong (Seoul)
View from Namsan Mountain (Seoul)
Guard Changing Ceremony at Gyeongbokgung Palace (Seoul)
Visit Gyeongbokgung Palace (Seoul)
Half day DMZ Tours incl. Q&A session with a North Korean defector (Seoul)
K-pop Dance Class (Seoul)
Geumsunsa Temple stay incl. Temple tour, evening & morning Buddhis Ceremony, singing bowl meditation, traditional vegetarian dinner & breakfast (Seoul)
Hike/activities in Seoraksan National Park (Sokcho)
Gatbae boat to Abai Village (Sokcho)
Dinner at fish market (Sokcho)
Traditional Liquor Tasting (Sokcho hostel)
Cycling tour of Gyeongju old town
Visit Daereungwon Tumuli Park incl. Chunmachong Ancient Tombs (Gyeongju)
Visit Cheomseongdae Astronomical Observatory (Gyeongju)
Visit Gamcheon Culture Village (Busan)
Songdo Marine Cable Car ride (standard cabin, Busan)
Walk through BIFF Square (Busan)
Visit Haedong Yonggungsa Temple (Busan)
Hike Seongsan Ilchulbong (Jeju)
Half-day hike along Jeju Olle Trail No.7 & Oedolgae Rock (Jeju)
Visit Jungbang Waterfall (Jeju)
Visit Daepo Jusangjeolli Cliff (Jeju)
Yacht Sailing Tour (Jeju)
Farewell Jeju Black Pork BBQ dinner

dayInfo.description: Seoul: Prepare to kick off your South Korea adventure tour by meeting your guide and fellow travelers at the hostel in the afternoon. Get started with a pre-departure briefing to learn all about your trip and get to know your group while trying out Taekwondo and practicing some basic Korean phrases. Next, head out to explore Myeongdong and enjoy a welcome dinner with your fellow travellers! Bond over some delicious Korean food and Soju - before making your way up to the top of Namsan Mountain, where you'll be treated to breathtaking views of Seoul at night. Take a stroll through the "padlocks of love" and enjoy the romantic atmosphere before making your way to the top of the Seoul N Tower for even better views of the city. Later, take the cable car down and enjoy a walk back to your accommodation in the district of Myeongdong. Spend some time strolling around and exploring the area or grab an early night to prepare for your first full day tomorrow!

Seoul: Get ready for a cultural immersion as you explore the ancient side of Seoul today. Rise early and take the metro to Gyeongbokgung Palace, where you'll witness the Royal Guard Changing Ceremony and have the chance to tour the palace grounds. For an even more immersive experience, consider renting a hanbok and strolling around the palace like a true Joseon Dynasty royal. This afternoon you have a choice of what to do. Either head to Bukchon Hanok Village, a traditional Korean neighborhood lined with centuries-old wooden homes. Or, perhaps you would prefer to do one of the following: - Insadong Art Street - Take a visit to Gangnam District - Rent a bike and cycle along Han river - Visit HIKR ground - cultural centre where you can record your own music video and learn about K-wave There is even an option to take part in a Perfume Making Class. Choose your scents and combine to make your own personalised perfume. Let us know if you would be interested in this! In the evening, you can have food and drinks in the Euljiro/Itaewon districts.

Seoul: On the 3rd day of your South Korea adventure tour, you'll be visiting the Korean Demilitarized Zone. After grabbing breakfast at Imjingak, you'll head to Dora Observatory to see the nearest North Korean villages through binoculars. You might even see some people in the streets if you're lucky! Next, you'll descend into the 3rd Tunnel created by North Koreans, taking you as close as 170m to North Korea. After this unique experience, you'll begin your journey back to Seoul with a special opportunity to talk to a North Korean defector on the bus. Once you're back in Seoul, you'll have a chance to try out a K-Pop Dance Class and then enjoy a night out in the lively district of Hongdae, known for its endless restaurant and bar options.

Geumsunsa Temple: Start the day with a relaxed morning in Seoul, giving you time to wander the streets, recharge, or simply soak in the city’s vibrant energy. Later, we’ll whisk you away to Geumsunsa Temple for an authentic templestay. A private transfer brings us mid-afternoon, leaving time to settle in before diving into the rhythm of temple life. Enjoy a guided tour and a nourishing vegetarian dinner to fuel your first evening. As night falls, immerse yourself in the drum and bell rituals, Buddhist chanting, and a soothing singing bowl meditation. Take a quiet moment to reflect or explore the tranquil temple grounds before turning in early, refreshed and ready for tomorrow’s adventures.

Sokcho & Seoraksan National Park: Start the morning the traditional way with a peaceful Buddhist dawn chanting ceremony, followed by a simple temple breakfast. After tidying your room and returning your temple stay uniform, it’s time to say goodbye to monastery life and hop on the private bus for the next adventure: Sokcho, on Korea’s north-eastern coast. Arriving late morning, we’ll head straight into the stunning landscapes of Seoraksan National Park. Embark on a rewarding hike to Ulsanbawi Rock for breathtaking panoramic views. Prefer a gentler pace? Take the waterfall trail or hop on the cable car to another scenic peak — or do both if you’re feeling adventurous! Afterward, enjoy lunch at the park entrance before heading to Sokcho town, where we’ll cross the river on a gatbae to reach Abai, a quaint village originally settled by North Korean refugees. In the evening, join your Adventure Leader for a food market tour, sampling the best of Sokcho’s culinary delights. From fresh seafood straight from the market to local favourites like Manseok’s sticky sweet-and-sour fried chicken, it’s the perfect introduction to the city’s vibrant food scene. Finish the night with a traditional Korean liquor tasting, guided by your Adventure Leader, and experience the local flavours in a truly authentic way.

Gyeongju: This morning, get ready for an early start as we travel along Korea’s scenic East Coast to Gyeongju, the country’s ancient capital and a city brimming with history. Once you arrive, drop off your bags and prepare for an afternoon of exploration. Hop on two wheels for a guided cycling tour of Gyeongju’s old town. Ride through charming streets with your Adventure Leader, stopping at highlights like the Chunmachong Ancient Tombs at Daereungwon Tumuli Park and Cheomseongdae, East Asia’s oldest surviving astronomical observatory. The guided ride takes about 45 minutes on mostly flat roads, but you’re welcome to continue exploring on your bike at your own pace afterward. Not keen on cycling? No problem — the old town is compact and easy to explore on foot, and around 90 minutes is enough to see the main sights. In the evening, opt for a traditional Korean set meal in a hanok, a beautiful wooden house that adds atmosphere to your dining experience (approx. 17,000 KRW, drinks extra). After dinner, the night is yours to explore. A highly recommended stop is Anapji Pond, where the illuminated gardens and reflections create a picture-perfect evening. Entrance is 3,000 KRW, and while your Adventure Leader may not join, clear directions will be provided.

Busan: Check out from the hostel and take the bus to Sin Gyeongju station, where you will catch a high-speed train to Busan. Upon arrival, you will board a private bus for a day of exploring. Your first stop is Gamcheon Culture Village, a must-visit destination with its colorful houses and charming alleyways. Then, head to Songdo where you'll take a ride on the Marine Cable Car and enjoy the stunning coastal views. Next, visit BIFF Square in Nampo-dong, the location of the annual Busan International Film Festival. Try some local food from the street vendors, and don't forget to try the Busan hotteok. Finally, make your way to your hostel in Haeundae, where you can unwind and relax for the evening.

Busan: Spend a day exploring Busan, starting with a visit to Haedong Yonggungsa Temple. This Buddhist temple is perched on the cliffs of the coastline and offers stunning views. For some more relaxation, head to Spa Land in Centum City, located in Busan's largest shopping complex. Enjoy South Korea's high-quality jjimjilbang and indulge in saunas, cold rooms, jacuzzis, and more. In the evening, enjoy local delicacies with your fellow travelers. After the sun sets, admire the beautiful light show on Gwangan Bridge from the shore, or opt for an evening boat cruise around the bay.

Busan: Take advantage of a free morning to explore Busan at your leisure. You can either venture out on your own or participate in some of the recommended activities. For example, you can take a trip on the Haeundae Blueline, a coastal railway, or visit the observatory of the second-tallest building in Korea to enjoy the views. Alternatively, embark on the Igidae Coastal Walk and Oryukdo Skywalk, or just relax on the beach. In the afternoon, collect your belongings from the hostel and head to the port where you will board an overnight ferry to Jeju Island. Make sure to take in the stunning views of the city from the top deck as you depart. You can spend the rest of the evening relaxing with your fellow travelers in the lounge areas or heading to bed early in preparation for an early start in the morning.

Jeju Island: After having breakfast begin your day with a private transfer to Oedolgae Rock and embark on a trek along the Jeju Olle Trail. Enjoy the stunning natural scenery along the way, including volcanic cliffs and fields of bright yellow canola. Proceed to Seongsan Ilchulbong for a morning hike with breathtaking views. This UNESCO World Heritage Site is renowned for its unique formation, which was shaped by hydrovolcanic eruptions over 5,000 years ago. Here you have the opportunity to see the Haenyeo Divers (weather/availability dependent). They are an iconic symbol of Jeju island’s rich cultural heritage. These incredible female divers, some in their 60s and beyond, free-dive without oxygen tanks to harvest seafood like abalone and sea urchins from the ocean depths. The rest of the afternoon is free for your own exploration, and you can seek our recommendations if needed.

Jeju Island: Start the day with a visit to the stunning Daepo Jusangjeolli Cliffs. Admire these volcanic rock formations in all their glory! Set sail on a Yacht Sailing Tour and admire the views of the island. There is an option to practice fishing on the boat, and you can throw back anything you catch. The afternoon is then free for you to enjoy as you wish, such as taking a visit to Cheonjiyeon Waterfall, Sunset Drinks at The Cliff or taking a walk around Maritime Park. Tonight, enjoy a Farewell Jeju Pork BBQ for dinner!

Jeju Island: Safe travels and thank you for choosing Dragon Trip! We hope you had an amazing time exploring the wonders of South Korea with us. The tour will end in Jeju but if you wish for our team to book the flight from Jeju-Seoul, let us know and we can arrange this. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or if you're interested in booking another adventure with us in the future.

generalInfo: A destination of natural wonder, culinary delights and cityscapes, South Korea is a rewarding trip for any traveller. On this nine-day exploration, you’ll discover Korea’s Demilitarised Zone, tuck into a feast at an all-you-can-eat Korean BBQ restaurant, hike through the amazing scenery of Seoraksan Mountain, wander through the colourful Gamcheong Culture Village, spend a night in a traditional Hanok house and discover the charisma of Busan, from seaside Haedong Temple to the stories of Haeyno divers.

dayInfo.title: Seoul.
dayInfo.description: Annyeong! Welcome to South Korea. Your adventure begins in Seoul – the capital city of high-tech gadgetry, soaring skyscrapers and delicious eats. If you arrive early, explore this metropolis at your own pace and discover how ancient traditions come together with the modern in one of Asia's great cities. You’ll have a welcome meeting at 4 pm this afternoon. After, your leader will take you to visit the renowned Gwangjang Market for a street food dinner tour. Here, you’ll find some of Korea’s streeside favourites like mayak gimbap (rice rolls), mandu (North Korean dumplings), bindaetteok (mung bean pancake) and kimchi. Later, follow your leader to the top of Naksan to see Seoul’s skyline at night.

dayInfo.title: Seoul.
dayInfo.description: Embrace an early morning for a tour of the Demilitarised Zone (DMZ). From the South Korean side of the Zone, you’ll learn how this peninsula has been divided since the devastating Korean War. You’ll visit the Third Tunnel of Aggression, the Unification Bridge, Imjingak Park and the Dora Observatory. In the afternoon, explore Gyeongbukgung Palace – the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty – and the traditional Bukchon Hanok Village. Your tour will finish in the late afternoon in Bukchon, where you might like to stay as there's plenty to explore. Or, maybe visit Namsan Mountain or Yongsan's War Museum.

dayInfo.title: Sokcho.
dayInfo.description: In the morning, take a local express bus to the east coast city of Sokcho. When you arrive, head to the Sokcho Central Market for an insight into how the locals go about their daily lives and maybe try a few local snacks. After, you’ll have some free time before heading to Abai – a small island village in Sokcho that, for generations, has been a haven for refugees fleeing the war from North Korea. Getting here is half the fun – you’ll have to work together to pull a rope on a small barge to get to the other side. Visit a North Korean refugee’s family and listen to their story of how history reshaped their life. Then, take part in a cooking demonstration and learn how to make giant Korean dumplings. Have dinner together, maybe trying things like home-cooked japchae (stir fried glass noodles), kimbap (Korea’s version of sushi rolls) and rice beer. The payment the family receives for this dinner will be contributed to the Abai Village Preservation Society.

dayInfo.title: Sokcho.
dayInfo.description: Head to Seoraksan – Korea’s most well-known mountain and the third highest in the peninsula – and go for a hike to see the views of this UNESCO World Heritage Site. The afternoon and evening is yours to explore Sokcho. Maybe visit Yeoung Geum Jung Pagoda, which is on the coast overlooking the sea. Or hire a bike and ride around the scenic Yeongrang Lake. Maybe try Korean hotpot for dinner or visit Sokcho Expo Tower. Otherwise, you could take a walk along Sokcho Harbor or opt for a relaxing soak at the Cheoksan Hot Springs.

dayInfo.title: Andong.
dayInfo.description: Hit the road this morning for Andong Hahoe Folk Village. This settlement is easy to walk around, so you’ll join your leader on a stroll through the traditional houses (including the one that hosted Queen Elizabeth II in 1999). Visit the remnants of a traditional school to see how students studied in the past, then walk to Buyongdae Hill for a bird’s eye view of the village, dotted with traditional Hanok houses. Being a traditional Korean outpost, there may also be masked dancers performing in town. To learn more about this ritual, why not visit the nearby mask museum. Later, head to your accommodation for the night – staying in an authentic Hanok (traditional Korean house) is a unique experience and the perfect opportunity to gain more insight into local life.

dayInfo.title: Busan.
dayInfo.description: After saying goodbye to your host family, make your way to Busan – South Korea’s second-largest city is home to mountains, beaches, hot springs and deliciously fresh seafood. When you arrive, you’ll have the opportunity to talk to a Haenyeo diver. Haenyeo (sea women) dive into the sea to collect clams, sea urchins and oysters and are famous for being able to hold their breath for a very long time. A dwindling industry, this has been a main source of income for the divers (predominantly female) to support their families through changing times. Visit the local Haenyeo community centre and meet with an ex-diver to hear about her experience, the changes Busan has gone through and her life now. Then visit Haedong Temple – the famous Buddhist temple by the sea. Explore this rare gem, backdropped by the ocean, before going to Gamcheong Culture Village for an overview of the city. There are a few different spots to watch the sunset, so maybe grab a few of your group members and head to one of the many scenic viewpoints.

dayInfo.title: Busan.
dayInfo.description: This morning, head to the seaside town of Ikidae and take a coastal walk (and optional plogging). Then, visit to a local ‘Smart Farm’ – this incubation site is where startups are growing crops in recycled shipping containers, as well as turning them into shops and cafes. The rest of the day is yours. Tonight, maybe take an optional night cruise and see Busan from the water as the sun goes down. You can also visit Haeundae Night Market or see the buskers on the boardwalk.

dayInfo.title: Seoul.
dayInfo.description: This morning, jump on the KTX Bullet Train and head back to Seoul. When you arrive, the rest of afternoon is yours to explore. Perhaps venture out and explore the National Museum, Leeum Art Museum or check out the huge range of shopping in Seoul’s Dongdaemun. This evening, join your travel pals for the final group dinner at an all-you-can-eat barbecue feast – you can't leave Korea without experiencing this iconic dish!

dayInfo.title: Seoul.
dayInfo.description: Your adventure comes to an end after breakfast today. With no activities planned, you’re free to leave at any time. If you’d like to spend more time in Seoul, just speak to your booking agent.

generalInfo: One of the world’s most progressive economies, yet still technically at war for more than 70 years with its northern neighbour, South Korea is something of an enigma. Sandwiched between the Yellow Sea to the west and the Sea of Japan to the east, it provides a fascinating mix of the traditional and the innovative, where five thousand years of culture rubs shoulders with some of the most advanced technology on earth.Beginning in the country’s thriving capital, Seoul, this remarkable adventure takes us from the vibrancy of its most progressive city, on a journey that encompasses the Korean War and the once powerful kingdoms of the Joseon and Silla. We will visit the evocative site of the infamous DMZ along the 38th Parallel, as well as a dazzling collection of World Heritage Sites that hark back to the golden ages of Buddhist art and Korean culture. We will also savour the colours and flavours of local markets and local cuisine and enjoy the pristine beauty of some of the country’s most picturesque national parks.A feast for all the senses, this will be a journey into the very heart of the paradox that is South Korea.

dayInfo.description: Tour Starts in Seoul: We begin our journey in Seoul, a city whose rich mix of ancient traditions and modern innovation has seen it rise to become one of East Asia’s cultural, technological and historic hubs. Tracing its origins back to the 18th century BCE, the city today is home to nearly 10 million people, as well as no fewer than five UNESCO World Heritage Sites, a vibrant arts scene and some of the finest museums and markets in the country. The tour today starts at the hotel with the rest of the day at leisure.

Seoul: Inwangsan Mountain Trail & City Tour: Following breakfast, we'll journey along the city’s Inwangsan Mountain Trail this morning, renowned for its rugged beauty and striking rock formations. Returning to the capital later we then explore something of the city’s historic heart, visiting Gwanghwamun Plaza and the Joseon palace of Gyeongbokgung, before witnessing the ceremonial changing of the guard at the Gwanghwamun Gate. Finishing with a wander amongst the cultural treasures of Insadong and the traditional architecture of Ikseon-dong Hanok Village, we’ll end the day with a welcome dinner at a local restaurant.Note: hike along the Inwangsan Mountain Trail will have an approximate duration of 3 hours 30 minutes and be 4KM in length.

Day 3: Seoul: DMZ Visit & Market Tour: One of the most politically sensitive borders on earth, the Korean Demilitarised Zone (DMZ) divides the peninsula roughly in half. Some four kilometres in depth and around 250 kilometres long, it divides the north and south near the 38th parallel. A semi-private tour of the area this morning will include a visit to the Freedom Bridge and the DMZ Museum, before we transfer back to Seoul for lunch. The afternoon then sees us visiting the recreated village of Namsangol Hanok, with its Joseon-era architecture, before we swap tradition for iconic Korean street food and the lively bustle and dynamic nightlife of Myeong-dong.Note: The visit to the DMZ is subject to being cancelled last minute due to local security conditions.

Seoul - Train to Andong: Hahoe World Mask Museum: Departing the South Korean capital this morning we travel next to the eastern city of Andong, considered by many to be the spiritual and cultural heart of the country. Travelling by high-speed train we arrive in time to enjoy a tour around the city. A treasure house of Korean customs and architecture, we begin with a visit to the extensive Hahoe World Mask Museum, before attending a traditional performance of a Hahoe Mask Dance show. A chance to enjoy the serene beauty of the UNESCO Site of Byeongsanseowon Confucian Academy will then be followed by an opportunity to savour Andong’s renowned local cuisine.

Gayasan: Haeinsa Temple Stay: Transfer to the nearby city of Daegu this morning, where the bustling Seomun Market awaits us. One of the largest traditional markets in South Korea, Seomun’s narrow alleyways provide a perfect place to soak up some local colour, and perhaps find a souvenir or two. From here we then travel to Gayasan National Park, where the majestic 9th century temple of Haeinsa sits resplendent on the slopes of Mount Gayasan. Home to the most complete collection of Buddhist texts, the temple is another of South Korea’s magnificent UNESCO World Heritage Sites and, interestingly, also our home for the evening.Note: The overnight temple stay is an authentic Buddhist experience and as such, enforces guests to stay in same-gender accommodation. This is to uphold a sense of spiritual discipline and avoid distraction during a time of meditation and reflection. Room configuration varies and each room will consist of two or four beds and have an en suite. Four bed rooms may include bunk beds.

Gyeongju: Cycle tour and Korean tea ceremony: An early start sees us attending the temple’s morning ceremony, before we depart the mountains for the coastal city of Gyeongju. Once the capital of the ancient Silla kingdom, Gyeongju is filled with palaces, temples and tombs that attest to the rise and importance of both the Silla and Joseon eras. Our first visit on arrival will be to the Gyeongju National Museum, home to a vast collection of artefacts, relics and royal treasures, before we move on to Cheomseongdae, the oldest astronomical observatory in East Asia. A bicycle ride through the Daereungwon Tomb Complex will then be rounded off with a traditional Korean tea ceremony before we transfer to our hotel.Note: cycle helmets are provided

Gyeongju - Gyeongju National Park: Following breakfast this morning we take a journey through the lush landscapes of the Gyeongju National Park, home to the iconic settings of the Bulguksa Temple and the Seokguram Grotto. One of the most famous and important temples in Korea, Bulguska is considered a masterpiece of the golden age of Buddhist art and, along with nearby Seokguram, occupies pride of place amongst South Korea’s UNESCO treasures. A visit to the scenic setting of Bomun Lake will then be followed by an evening’s walk to Woljeong Bridge and the historical ‘gateway’ that connects the Silla palaces to the south.

Gyeongju - Busan: Haedong Yonggungsa Temple & Haeundae Beach: Departing Gyeongju after breakfast we head next for South Korea’s second largest city. Known for its beaches and its seafood, Busan lies on the southeastern tip of the Korean Peninsula and is home to the country’s busiest port. After dropping off luggage at our hotel, we then head out to explore something of the city, visiting the Haedong Yonggungsa Temple and the popular setting of Haeundae Beach. In the company of our guide we will enjoy a food-focused walking tour around Haeundae’s bustling streets, followed perhaps by a chance to experience a little something of the area’s vibrant nightlife.

Busan: Cooking Class & Gamcheon and Dakbatgol Village Tours: An insightful food experience is on the menu for this morning, where we will learn more about authentic local specialities and traditional culinary techniques. Busan’s varied cuisine reflects its historical importance as a major refugee centre during the Korean War and today provides an opportunity to celebrate and savour something of its culinary legacy. The food theme then continues with a visit to BIFF Square, known for its bustling streets and vibrant food stalls, before immersing ourselves in the art culture and charming streets of Gamcheon and the Dakbatgol Mural Village. Day’s end sees us enjoying the sunset on Gwangalli Beach.

Busan - Jeonju: Juknokwon Bamboo Forest: We turn west today, towards the bamboo forests of Damyang County. Initially our journey takes us via the temple of Ssanggyesa, a historic Buddhist sanctuary that sits amongst the picturesque landscapes of the Hadong region. Nestling amongst the serene peaks of the Jiri Mountain range, the temple’s tranquil surroundings provide an idyllic spot to break our journey. From here we continue to Damyang, where we find a picturesque patchwork of tea plantations, historic gardens and rich bamboo forests that provide a chance to sample local bamboo tea and walk amongst towering bamboo and majestic sequoia trees.

Jeonju: Mudeungsan National Park Hike: After breakfast at a local restaurant this morning we transfer to Mudeungsan National Park, to enjoy a gentle hike to the Jeungsimsa Temple. Skirting the edge of Mudeungsan Mountain, the park is a relative newcomer to the list of South Korea’s national parks and overlooks Gwangju, a city often cited as the birthplace of Korean democracy. The temple itself lies amongst the western foothills and can date its origins back to the Silla kingdom of the 6th century. Lunch at a local restaurant today will be followed by some free time back in Namwon this afternoon.Note: the hike through Mudeungsan National Park will be 40 minutes to Jeungsimsa Temple and 40 minutes back to the starting point. The walk is a light-moderate hike with a combination of well-maintained trails and natural terrain, with some rocky sections and gentle inclines.

Jeonju - Seoul: Jeonju Hanok Village and Hwaseong Fortress: Departing Namwon after breakfast we head north towards Jeonju this morning, a city whose culinary and cultural antecedents can be traced back over 1300 years. A visit to the city’s Nambu Market affords an opportunity for some more local interaction, before we head for the well-preserved traditional hanok village of Jeonju. Continuing on to Suwon, we then pay a visit to the UNESCO setting of Hwaseong Fortress, built during the late Joseon Period (1777-1800), before completing the journey back to Seoul for our final evening and a farewell dinner at a local restaurant.
Tour ends in Seoul: The tour ends after breakfast.

generalInfo:
This is South Korea as experienced by someone who lives it for themselves.

We’ve carefully crafted this journey to connect Korea’s standout cultural highlights with everyday local life, led by a dedicated group leader. They are not just a guide – they’re a resident, fluent in Korean and English, who brings real-time insight and flexibility to each day of the tour.

Over ten days, you’ll move from the capital of Seoul to the former royal seat of Gyeongju and hit the coastal city of Busan. This route is all about contrasts: centuries-old palaces and backstreet BBQ joints, traditional hanok homes and neon-lit markets, ancient temples and contemporary art galleries.

In Seoul, explore Gyeongbokgung Palace and wander through the restored hanok lanes of Bukchon before stepping into the high energy of Gwangjang Market. With your Insider’s finger on the cultural pulse, you might also duck into a gallery or bar that’s brand new on the scene – the kind of place you’d never find travelling independently.

In Gyeongju, Korea’s “museum without walls,” sleep in a traditional hanok house and explore ancient tombs, Confucian academies and Buddhist relics that tell the story of Korea’s Silla past. Then, in Busan, try seafood caught that morning at Jagalchi Market before visiting the colourful Gamcheon Culture Village or soaking in a local spa.

This tour is ideal for curious travellers who want more than a South Korea checklist. With an expert insider to reveal the stories behind each stop, Soul of Korea offers a deeper look at the country’s culture, cuisine and day-to-day rhythm – perfect for first-time visitors who want to feel connected as well as inspired.

dayInfo.description: Seoul | Breakfast Spend a full day walking Seoul with your guide, blending the city's grandest sights with its trendiest corners. Wander through a traditional hanok village, witness the changing of the guard at Gyeongbok Palace, and pause by the Cheonggyecheon stream, where your Insider guide will share stories of Seoul’s history. Sample street food at Gwangjang Market, then gather round the grill for your first Korean barbecue, learning Korean dining and drinking etiquette along the way. You’ll explore whatever’s hot right now in Seoul– perhaps a pop-up bar or a light festival – before taking a day to explore on your own, armed with local tips tailored just for you.

Chuncheon day trip | Breakfast Escape the city for a day and head to Chuncheon, a nostalgic favourite for generations of Koreans. Pedal the Gangchon Rail Bike along an old train line once nicknamed the “Love Train”, passing mountain views and quirky themed tunnels. Cross Soyang Lake by boat and settle in for a local lunch of jeon pancakes, fried mountain ginseng and makgeolli rice wine. A gentle forest trail leads to Cheonpyeongsa Temple, where you’ll find a centuries-old monastery alongisde a waterfall and a statue from a local legend. It’s a peaceful, offbeat contrast to Seoul’s fast pace – and one we love.

Busan | Breakfast Busan is where locals go to unwind – a vibrant coastal city of street art, seafood and sea views. Start your day at Jagalchi fish market, navigating tanks of sea creatures before heading upstairs to sample that morning’s catch. At Haedong Yonggungsa Temple, perched on a rocky coastline, walk past turtle and Buddha statues for panoramic ocean views. In Gamcheon Cultural Village, winding alleys are lined with colour-blocked houses and murals. Come evening, you will be guided through Haeundae’s bar scene, stopping at a mix of lively spots for craft beer or snacks. In you free time, we recommend winding down with a soak at Spa LAND.

Gyeongju | Breakfast Once the capital of the Silla Kingdom, Gyeongju is South Korea’s most history-rich city – a place where ancient tombs, temples and observatories sit side by side. Visit Bulguksa Temple and the hillside Seokguram Grotto, both UNESCO-listed and deeply atmospheric. As night falls, stroll past the lantern-lit Anapji Pond and Cheomseongdae, Asia’s oldest observatory. In the hills beyond, explore Yangdong Folk Village, a chance to capture Korean traditional life in a village where people still live and work today. Back in town, Hwangridan-gil offers a modern twist –indie boutiques, street art and hanok rooftop bars.

Seoul | Your final stop in Seoul offers a fresh perspective, swapping palaces for pop culture in the lively neighbourhood of Hongdae. Known for its street performers and creative energy, it’s a fitting end to your journey. Your hotel matches the mood – complete with a vinyl library, Michelin-starred chef menu, and even a basement skate park. There’s time to pick up last-minute K-Beauty favourites or the snacks you’ve been craving since day one. Then, gather for one final dinner with your Insider and group – a chance to toast the trip with a heartfelt geonbae before heading home.

generalInfo: Zicasso’s 10-day cultural South Korea tour is a series of profound, private encounters with the nation’s heritage at heart. A graceful dialogue between the grandeur of ancient dynasties and the vibrant energy of avant-garde modernity, witness the volcanic peak of a sacred mountain, wander through subterranean majesty in a lava tube, and experience the quiet intensity of a master artisan crafting in their private studio. Through exclusive access and curated insights, you will have an intimate connection to the places, philosophies, and people that define the spirit of South Korea.

dayInfo.title: Seoul - Arrive In an Overture of Light and Flavor from the City's Apex
dayInfo.description: Upon your arrival at Incheon International Airport, a private transfer will escort you to your luxury accommodations. As twilight approaches, your immersion begins. Your private car will convey you to the base of Namsan Mountain, where pre-arranged access allows you to bypass the public queues for the cable car, ensuring a seamless and tranquil ascent. As you glide upwards, the sprawling city takes shape over the Han River, the distant mountains, and height of N Seoul Tower. At the tower’s highest point, you are personally welcomed to a fine-dining restaurant renowned for its romantic ambiance and unparalleled views. Your table awaits within the slowly revolving dining room, for an ever-changing, 360-degree panorama of Seoul. The atmosphere is one of refined intimacy, where the clinking of fine crystal and hushed conversation create the perfect setting for your first night. Savor an exquisite French-inspired dinner, with signature dishes such as Korean beef sirloin or delicate lobster, each plate a work of culinary art. Following dinner, descend back into the city to explore Seoul’s sophisticated dessert culture. Your destination is a premium dessert emporium in the chic neighborhood. The air is rich with aromas of fresh-baked bread, fine chocolate, and artisanal coffee.

dayInfo.title: Seoul - Listen for Whispers of the Past in Hanok Alleys and an Artisan's Studio
dayInfo.description: Your morning is dedicated to a private, contemplative walk through Bukchon Hanok Village, a living museum nestled between two royal palaces. Led by a local historian with deep knowledge of Korean architecture, your tour trades the crowded main paths for quiet, winding alleys. The elegant, curved tile roofs of traditional hanok houses create a sense of tranquility against the backdrop of Seoul’s modern skyline. Your guide illuminates the architectural principles of living in harmony with nature, explaining how these centuries-old homes remain models of sustainable design. In the afternoon, you are welcomed into the private studio of a master calligrapher. His studio is a sanctuary from the bustling city; the experience deeply sensory and meditative. You will learn to grind the inkstick on the inkstone, feeling the texture change as the ink forms. The master will personally guide your hand, teaching you the proper way to hold the brush and the focused breathing required for each stroke. This session provides a foundational understanding of the aesthetic and spiritual principles you will see reflected throughout your journey.

dayInfo.title: Seoul - Follow the Echoes of a Dynasty in Stone and Memory
dayInfo.description: Today’s journey takes you beyond the capital to the monumental legacy of the Joseon Dynasty. A private vehicle awaits to transport you south to Suwon, home to the magnificent Hwaseong Fortress, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. You will explore this 18th-century marvel as a student of history, accompanied by a private guide with expertise in Joseon-era military architecture. Your guide will bring the fortress to life, recounting the story of its creator, King Jeongjo, whose vision was a powerful blend of filial piety, political ambition, and scientific innovation. Walk the formidable three-and-a-half-mile perimeter, feeling the texture of the massive stone and brick walls under your hand. Returning to Seoul in the afternoon, engage with a more recent, more painful chapter of Korean history at The War Memorial of Korea. Given the museum's vast scale, your expert guide is essential in providing a focused and poignant narrative that cuts through the immense collection to the humanity at the heart of the story. "Statue of Brothers" is a sculpture depicting two soldiers, one from the North, one from the South, in a heart-wrenching embrace. It’s a potent symbol of a nation divided.

dayInfo.title: Seoul - Explore the Dialogue Between Ancient Treasures and Contemporary Vision
dayInfo.description: Explore the dynamic conversation between Korea’s priceless artistic heritage and its vibrant, boundary-pushing contemporary art scene. Your morning begins at the LEEUM Museum of Art, an architectural masterpiece in its own right. A private docent will guide you through the museum's three distinct buildings, designed by world-renowned architects Mario Botta, Jean Nouvel, and Rem Koolhaas. Your tour is structured as a dialogue. In Museum 1, immerse yourself in the serene beauty of traditional Korean art. Stand in awe before the ethereal glow of Joseon dynasty white porcelain and the rustic, whimsical forms of buncheong ceramics, Transition to Museum 2, a starkly modern space of black steel and glass designed by Nouvel, housing a world-class collection of contemporary art by Korean and international masters. Building on your museum experience, the afternoon takes you to the streets of the Samcheong-dong neighborhood in the historic Jongno district and the epicenter of Seoul's contemporary art world. Accompanied by a local art specialist, embark on a curated gallery walk, visiting a selection of Seoul’s most influential art spaces. Step from a quiet, traditional alley into the minimalist interior of a gallery or explore an experimental installation at a pioneering art center.

dayInfo.title: Seoul - Journey to the Edge of a Divided Nation
dayInfo.description: Today offers a powerful narrative of contrasts. It takes you from the world’s most tense border to the heart of Seoul’s most creative and hopeful neighborhood. Your day begins with a solemn journey north to the DMZ for an educational experience led by a private guide with deep expertise in the history and geopolitics of the Korean War. Your exclusive tour focuses on the Joint Security Area (JSA), the "truce village" where North and South Korean soldiers stand face-to-face. The sensory experience is one of palpable tension: the profound, unnerving silence of the zone, broken only by the wind and the sharp, disciplined movements of the guards. After the intensity of the morning, the evening provides a necessary and deliberate shift in tone and energy. You will be chauffeured to Seongsu-dong, the vibrant district often called the "Brooklyn of Seoul." This is a neighborhood in the midst of a creative renaissance, where former shoe factories and red-brick warehouses have been reborn as avant-garde art galleries, independent boutiques, and artisanal cafés. Guided by a local cultural insider, immerse yourself in an electric atmosphere filled with the aroma of specialty coffee and the energy of fashion-forward locals exploring pop-up shops.

dayInfo.title: Gyeongju - Enter the Serene Kingdom of Silla's Grassy Tombs
dayInfo.description: Your journey continues as you travel via high-speed train to Gyeongju. Upon arrival and after settling into your accommodations, you will embark on a contemplative walk through the Daereungwon Tomb Complex. This otherworldly landscape is dotted with dozens of massive, grass-covered burial mounds, or tumuli , the final resting places of Silla kings, queens, and nobles. With your private guide, you will meander along the quiet paths of this park-like necropolis, the air filled with a sense of peace and reverence. The sight of the perfectly rounded green mounds against the sky is surreal and beautiful. Your guide will share the stories of the royalty buried beneath, bringing the silent landscape to life. As dusk settles over the ancient capital, make your way to a nearby marvel of science and spirit, the Cheomseongdae Observatory. Built during the reign of Queen Seondeok in the 7th century, it is the oldest surviving astronomical observatory in East Asia. As the structure is illuminated against the twilight sky, your guide will reveal the symbolism of its design. You will learn how its 365 granite stones represent the days of the year and its 27 layers of stone honor the 27th monarch of Silla.

dayInfo.title: Gyeongju - Find the Radiance of Gold Crowns and the Sanctity of a Mountain Temple
dayInfo.description: Your morning is dedicated to an exclusive encounter with the treasures of Gyeongju’s royal tombs at the Gyeongju National Museum. While the museum is open to the public, you will be met by a museum specialist for a private, in-depth tour focusing on the world-renowned collection of Silla gold crowns. Your specialist guide will point out the exquisite craftsmanship of these delicate treasures, fashioned from pure, paper-thin gold. You will learn the meaning behind their unique shamanistic symbolism, with the uprights representing the sacred world tree that connects heaven and earth. In the afternoon, make a spiritual journey to the slopes of Mount Tohamsan to the magnificent Bulguksa Temple, a masterpiece of Buddhist art and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Your visit will be timed to avoid the peak crowds, allowing for a more personal experience. Accompanied by a guide specializing in Buddhist philosophy and architecture, you will discover how the entire temple complex is a physical representation of the land of Buddha on Earth. The atmosphere is tranquil, one in which the gentle sound of wind chimes mingles with the distant echo of chanting and the scent of incense.

dayInfo.title: Jeju Island - Ascend a Volcano and Dine with the Women of the Sea
dayInfo.description: Today, you fly to a different Korea found on the volcanic island of Jeju, a land of dramatic natural beauty and unique cultural traditions. Your exploration begins with an ascent of Hallasan, a dormant volcano and South Korea’s highest mountain, recognized as a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. This is a bespoke trek led by a private ecological guide, tailored to your fitness and interests. Whether you choose a scenic and manageable trail like the Eoseungsaengak or a more challenging route, your guide will enrich the experience with insights into the mountain’s unique volcanic geology and diverse ecosystems, leading to a rewarding panoramic view of the entire island and the serene Baengnokdam crater lake nestled at its peak. In the evening, you will attend one of the most unique and poignant dining experiences in all of Korea. You will be a guest at an immersive culinary performance celebrating the lives of Jeju’s legendary female free-divers, the haenyeo . Sit at a circular table inspired by the traditional Bulteok , a sheltered fire pit where the divers warm themselves. A storyteller shares the powerful, real-life stories of these resilient women, some of whom are still diving in their 80s.

dayInfo.title: Jeju Island - Journey to the Center of the Earth and Greet the Dawn from a Volcanic Crown
dayInfo.description: Your final day on Jeju is a journey of geological wonders, from the fiery birth of the island to its subterranean secrets. It begins before dawn with a private, guided ascent of Seongsan Ilchulbong, the "Sunrise Peak.” This iconic volcanic tuff cone, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is one of Korea’s most sacred places to greet the new day. Your guide will lead you up the steep but well-maintained path in the quiet, pre-dawn stillness. The climb is invigorating, building anticipation for the spectacle to come. As the sun breaks over the horizon, it casts a breathtaking golden light across the ocean. From the heights of a volcanic crater, your afternoon takes you deep into the earth. Your private guide will lead you on an exploration of the Manjanggul Lava Tube, one of the longest and most well-preserved lava tunnels in the world. As you descend into the cave, you will feel an immediate drop in temperature as you shift into the subterranean world. The air is cool, damp, and filled with echoing silence. Dim lighting reveals the tunnel's incredible geological formations: lava stalactites, flowstones, and the world's largest known lava column, a towering monument of solidified magma.

dayInfo.title: Seoul - Depart for Home
dayInfo.description: After a leisurely breakfast, your private car will escort you to the fashionable district of Sinsa-dong to stroll along Garosu-gil, the famous tree-lined street known for its chic designer boutiques, art galleries, and sophisticated cafés. You may choose to visit a stylish café for a final, perfectly brewed coffee and an artisanal pastry, or visit a gallery while reflecting on the experiences of the past ten days. This is a moment to savor the city's contemporary ambiance one last time before your private transfer arrives to ensure a seamless and comfortable journey to Incheon International Airport for your flight home.

tourName: 8-Day K-Pop Demon Hunters Tour of Seoul: Tradition, Food, and Culture in South Korea
generalInfo: Our eight-day South Korea tour immerses you in the captivating world of K-Pop as a gateway to discovering ancient traditions, spiritual heritage, and modern cultural innovations. From royal palaces where mythological foxes infiltrated the courts to sacred mountains where shamans still perform protective rituals, experience the authentic heritage that inspired K-Pop Demon Hunters and more. Through exclusive access to celebrity styling sessions, professional recording studios, and traditional markets, lose yourself in the artistry of K-Pop and the timeless soul of Korea.

dayInfo.title: Seoul - Arrive in Seoul and Embrace the Idol Aesthetic
